Award.AwardTitle: Polynomial Optimization: Solution Methods and Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this project is to develop numerical tools for solving polynomial and tensor optimization models arising from engineering applications such as design of radar waveforms in signal processing, information extraction in magnetic resonance imaging, and gene expression data analysis in bioinformatics. An integrated approach for polynomial and tensor optimization models will be studied and tested in this project. The key components of the integrated approach include relaxation techniques, approximations to optimal solutions, randomized sampling techniques utilizing known structure of the model, and disciplined local improvements of feasible solutions. Numerical tools to be developed under the framework of the integrated approach will be investigated experimentally and validated using the data obtained from practical engineering applications including signal processing and bioinformatics. Performance of the algorithms developed from the project will be measured and compared against currently existing benchmarks.

If successful, the results of this research will enhance the effectiveness of methods for solving nonlinear optimization models where polynomial functions are found in the objective as well as in the constraints. In particular, such algorithms will lead to substantial practical improvements in radar waveform design, image processing, and data co-clustering analysis. As polynomial functions are known to be pervasive in the context of engineering design and decision making, success of the project will lead to broad societal benefits. Moreover, the proposed research addresses fundamental challenges in optimization theory, because most current research has not gone beyond polynomial models of degree 2; thus, results extending the theory beyond these models would constitute a major advance on the theory side, as well.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The world surrounding us is nonlinear, and polynomials can be used to approximate any smooth nonlinear functions. That is why polynomial optimization is an important subject to be studied. Because of its generality, polynomial optimization is also extremely challenging; that is, it is very difficult to come up with effective solution methods for finding good solutions. It turns out that the so-called convexity is an important structure underlying many computationally manageable nonlinear models. Unfortunately, polynomial optimization is not convex in general. Fortunately, unlike just any nonlinear functions, polynomials do have a structure after all: namely they are algebraic. Simply put, there is hope for polynomial optimization, but a lot of care must be taken. This project aimed to attack that problem head on. In fact, this project was one of the first systematic research efforts on polynomial optimization in terms of computation and approximation algorithms. Taking advantage of the algebraic structure of the problem, we developed a suite of approximation algorithms for various polynomial optimization models, and then applied them to solve practical problems from signal and image processing, statistics, and bioinformatics. It is fair to say that we have managed to touch upon the tip of an iceberg. Polynomial optimization has vast applications and has enormously interesting theoretical structure. This project has generated more new questions than provided answers to them. There are a lot of research topics to follow up on this project. During the execution of this project, over a dozen journal papers were published in top journals in the field of optimization. The PI delivered many invited lectures at various international conferences and workshops to promote the new techniques of polynomial optimization and its many far-reaching applications. Two Ph.D. students were trained in this project; one of them completed and landed on a faculty position.
